Name: Actinic Keratosis
tags: erythema, scaly, rough, white, yellow, red, horny, thickened, papule, plaque, sun+age, sun exposure, outdoor, non-emergent+pre-malignant, pre-cancerous
defin: Pre-cancerous scaly/rough lesions secondary to sun-exposure, ~1/1000 risk of transformation to SCC. Very common.
pe: Ill defined, scaly/rough erythematous papules/plaques on background of sun-damaged skin. Sandpaper-like/gritty on palpation. Most common on sun exposed areas (face, ears, scalp if bald, neck, etc).+Multiple phenotypes: Erythematous: typical AK lesion. Hypertrophic: thicker, rough papule/plaque. Cutaneous horn: firm hyperkeratotic outgrowth. Actinic cheilitis: confluent AKs on the lip. Pigmented: flat, tan-brown, scaly plaque.
diagnosis: Clinical. Biopsy persistent or worrisome lesions.
ddx: SCC in situ, superficial BCC, seborrheic keratosis, cutaneous lupus erythematosus
management: destructive: cryotherapy, electrodessication excision, and curettage (might be needed for hypertrophic/horns)+topicals (mechanism is destruction of rapidly growing cells or immune system modulation): ie 5-fluorouracil cream (for 2-4 wk)+Prevention: sunscreen, covering up
epid: Common with increasing age, outdoor occupation, fair skin, immunosuppression, lack of sunscreen, M>F. Less common in darker skin types (melanin is protective). Risk factors for transformation: immunosuppression, history of skin cancer, persistence of the AK.+While rare for solitary actinic keratosis to transform (~1/1000 risk to SCC), worth noting ~60% of SCC is from AK and that risk increases with persistence and # of lesions.
patho: UV radiation damage to keratinocytes from repeated sun exposure (especially UVB). Risk of transformation of AK to SCC (~1/1000), but higher likelihood if AK is persistent.
summary: AK is a very common pre-cancerous lesion secondary to sun-exposure more common in older patients. Diagnosis is primarily clinical, and management is aimed at destroying the pre-cancerous cells to prevent transformation into SCC, most often cyrotherapy.

Name: Atopic dermatitis
tags: erythema, scaly, rough, weeping, blisters, lichenification, dry, xerosis, excoriation+pediatric, adult, family history, atopy+non-emergent+inflammatory, atopic
defin: Also called eczema or atopic eczema. An extremely common chronic, pruritic inflammatory skin condition with a complex pathogenesis.
symptoms: Chronic/relapsing history of eczematous lesions associated with severe pruritus, with inflammation, lichenification, excoriations are secondary to relentless scratching. Itching is often worse at night.May be accompanied by asthma or allergic rhinitis, and is associated with psychosocial distress/psychiatric comorbidities.+Triggers: irritants (ie detergents, rough clothing), allergens, sweating, bacterial superinfection, stress
pe: Acute dermatitis is red (erythematous), weeping/crusted (exudative) and may have blisters (vesicles or bullae). Over time the dermatitis becomes chronic and the skin becomes less red but thickened (lichenified) and scaly. Cracking of the skin (fissures) can occur. Eczematous lesions often accompanied by xerosis and keratosis pilaris.+Lesion distribution is age specific. In infants, lesions characteristically occur on the face, scalp, neck, eyelids, and extensor surfaces of the extremities. In older children and adults, lesions occur on flexural surfaces such as the neck and the antecubital and popliteal fossae.
diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis, requiring 1) typical lesion morphology and age-specific distribution and 2) chronic/relapsing history. Consider skin biopsy, patch testing if allergic contact dermatitis is suspected
ddx: Ddx is long. Please see this link for a excellent guideline for more details. Otherwise, some pertinent conditions:+- Scabies, Seborrheic dermatitis, Contact dermatitis, Psoriasis, Erythroderma of other causes
management: Goal: symptom control, prevent or reduce recurrences. See flowchart from Toronto Notes 2020 below+Non-pharmacological+Avoid AD triggers. Screen for depressive symptoms and need for psychiatric referral+- liberal application of moisturizer, at least BID+- bathe in plain warm water up to once daily followed by moisturizer. Alternatively, can do bleach baths up to twice weekly (helps prevent superinfections) -> ½ cup household bleach to 151-L bathtub of warm water+pharmacologic therapy+- topical steroids: effective at symptom relief and flare prevention. Local side effects are fairly rare+- topical calcineurin inhibitors: tacrolimus 0.03%, 0.1% (Protopic®) and pimecrolimus 1% (Elidel®). Use as steroid-sparing agents in the long-term. Unlike steroids, no skin atrophy and safe for the face and neck. However, U.S. black box warning: rare cases of skin cancer and lymphoma reported, though no causal relationship is actually established+- for superinfections, consider topical mupirocin, retapamulin, ozenoxacin or fusidic acid. If widespread S. aureus infection, oral antibiotics (e.g. cloxacillin, cephalexin)
epid: Frequently affects infants, children, and young adult. Associated with personal or family history of atopy (asthma, hay fever), anaphylaxis, eosinophilia. Polygenic inheritance: one parent >60% chance for child. two parents >80% chance for child. Long-term condition with 1/3 of patients continuing to show signs of AD into adulthood. Patients with skin of colour appear to be at particular risk of developing lichen simplex and nodular prurigo with scratching and rubbing.
patho: A T-cell driven inflammatory process with epidermal barrier dysfunction. Complex pathophysiology involving genetic factors, epidermal barrier dysfunction, immunologic mechanisms, and environmental triggers.
summary: Atopic dermatitis is an extremely common chronic, pruritic inflammatory skin condition with a complex pathogenesis. Common findings vary with age and include pruritus and scaly erythematous patches and plaques and lichenification in the antecubital and popliteal fossae and on the eyelids, neck, and wrists. Superinfections (particularly S. aureus infections and eczema herpeticum) are common. Atopic dermatitis frequently resolves or lessens significantly by adulthood. First-line treatments include moisturizers, topical corticosteroids, and antihistamines as needed for pruritus. For disease unresponsive to topical therapy, consider systemic immunosuppressants.

Name: Cellulitis
tags: red, erythema, tender, unilateral, abscess, erosions+pediatric, adult, diabetes, immunocompromised+non-emergent+infection
defin: Bacterial infection of lower dermis and subcutaneous tissue, localized erythematous skin. Severe complications may include sepsis / nec fasc.
symptoms: Fever, malaise, chills. Development of localized tender rash.+PEARL: unilateral. If bilateral, consider other diagnoses.
pe: Erythematous tender lesion, not uniformly raised. Borders usually not clearly defined. May have vesicles, erosions, abscesses, or be associated with lymphangitis.
diagnosis: Diagnosis is mainly clinical. Helpful investigations include:+- leukocytosis on CBC+- elevated CRP +- peripheral swab or blood cultures+- US may be useful in the ED for ?fluid collections
ddx: Eczema/dermatitis, deep vein thrombosis, drug-reaction, psoriasis, erysipelas, venous ulcers, nec fasc
management: 1st line: cloxacillin or cefazolin (no PO)/cephalexin (Keflex, available PO)+2nd line: erythromycin or clindamycin.+Children: cefuroxime.+If DM (foot infections): TMP/SMX and metronidazole
epid: Quite common across all demographics.  affects people of all ages and races. Risk factors include prior episodes of cellulitis, tinea pedis, venous disease, current injury (ie trauma, surgical), immunodeficiency
patho: GAS, S. aureus (large sized wounds), H. influenzae (periorbital), Pasteurella multocida (dog/ cat bite)
summary: Cellulitis is a common infection of the lower dermal area often presenting with fever and localized usually unilateral erythematous tender lesion. Usually caused by gram positive bacteria, such as GAS and S. aureus. Diagnosis clinical, but may consider infectious BW. 1st line Abx cloxacillin / cephalexin in adults, cefuroxime pediatric.

Name: Impetigo
tags: red, itchy, ulcers, erosions, sores, honey coloured, bullous, purulent, crust+crowded, poor hygiene, pediatric, minor trauma+Non-emergent+infectious
defin: A highly contagious bacterial infection of the skin that is most common in young children/infants.
symptoms: Red, itchy sores that break open and ooze clear fluid/pus for a few days, followed by crusty yellow “honey-coloured” scabs. Sores can spread through touch, clothing and towels. Itching and soreness generally mild.+Less commonly presents as “bullous impetigo”, with larger blisters/vesicles.
pe: Nonbullous impetigo starts with a pink macule -> becomes a vesicle or pustule and then into erosions with a honey-coloured crust. Untreated impetigo usually resolves within 2 to 4 weeks. Bullous impetigo presents with small vesicles that evolve into flaccid transparent bullae. Both types usually heal without scarring
diagnosis: Clinical. On rare occasions may Gram stain and culture of lesion fluid.
management: Antibiotics: topical antibacterials (e.g. 2% mupirocin or fusidic acid (Canada only) tid -> continue for 7-10 d after resolution). If severe or resistent, consider systemic antibiotics (e.g. cloxacillin or cephalexin for 7-10 d)+Prevention and good wound care: remove crusts, use saline compresses, clean all minor cuts well and keep open wounds covered. Practice good hand hygiene, cut nails short, avoid close contact with others, use separate clothes. Patients can return to daily life if they’ve started Abx and keep all sores covered.
epid: Most common in children 2-5 years old. Risk factors: neglected minor trauma/broken skin, crowded conditions, poor hygiene
patho: Caused by GAS, S. aureus, or both. Complications are rare, but can include cellulitis, scarring, or development of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (if GAS)
summary: A highly contagious and fairly mild bacterial skin infection common in young children/infants, characterized by red, itchy sores that break open and ooze clear fluid/pus for a few days. Diagnosis is clinical and treatment involves antibiotics with good wound care.

Name: Melanoma
tags: dark, pigmented, flat, raised, growing, uneven+sun exposure, immunosuppresion, many nevi+Emergent+Cancerous, malignant
defin: Melanoma is a skin cancer of melanocytes with high metastatic potential.
symptoms: Usually insidious onset. Sometimes may be itchy or tender.
pe:
Can occur anywhere and metastasize anywhere. Most commonly arises in the skin, but can rarely grow on mucous membranes, eyes, and CNS. Common sites are the back (M) and calves (F).++The first sign is usually an unusual looking mole. Think ABCDE:+
  • Asymmetry of shape and colour
  • Border irregularity including smudgy or ill-defined margin
  • Colour variation and Change
  • Different or diameter >6mm
  • Evolving (enlarging, changing)
There are many clinical subtypes of MM, which differ in rate of spread, direction of growth, and morphology.
diagnosis: Low threshold for biopsy if suspicion for melanoma. BIOPSY MUST BE FULL DEPTH FOR STAGING. Excisional biopsy with 2-3mm margin is the gold standard, but incisional biopsies may be done in a pinch. Interestingly, punch biopsies are not recommended due to higher false-negative rates, unless the whole lesion may be contained.+Want a definitive diagnosis with Breslow depth.
ddx:
• benign: nevi, solar lentigo, seborrheic keratosis
  • malignant: pigmented BCC
management: GOAL: early diagnosis, biopsy, depth, staging, treatment+If an excisional biopsy can’t be done at your office, urgently refer. Immediate general surgery / oncology referral.
epid: Incidence: 1/75 (Canada), 1/50 (US). Risk factors: age, fair skin, red hair, positive FHx, many nevi, immunosuppression, sun exposure. Worse prognosis if: male, on scalp, hands, feet, late lesion, no pre-existing nevus present.
patho: Transformation of melanocytic stem cells. Normally, melanocytes are found in the basal epidermis. Benign growths of melanocytes creates moles and freckles. As genetic mutations accumulate, melanoma can change from in-situ to invasive to metastatic.++Cutaneous melanoma can arise from otherwise normal-appearing skin (in about 75% of melanomas) or from within a mole or freckle, which starts to grow larger and change in appearance.
summary: Melanoma is a malignant disease of melanocytes most often presenting as a unusual mole (think ABCDE). Biopsy and urgent diagnosis is crucial for long-term outcome.

Name: Molluscum contagiosum
tags: clusters, umbilicated, papules, red+pediatric, sexual, crowded, atopic dermatitis, immunosuppresion+non-emergent+viral, infectious
defin: A common viral skin infection of childhood causing localized clusters of umbilicated epidermal papules.
symptoms: Not associated with fever. Usually only painful when scratching or rubbing infects the bumps with bacteria. Sometimes itchy.
pe: Clusters of small discrete dome-shaped and umbilicated papules. The papules range in size from 1 to 6 mm and may be white, pink or brown, and are usually smooth/firm. Papule may contain white cheesy material. May be few or hundreds of papules on one individual. Common sites: eyelids, beard (likely spread by shaving), neck, axillae, trunk, perineum, buttocks. Usually painless, but may become inflamed, red, and swollen. Frequently induces surrounding dermatitis. As the papules resolve, they may become inflamed, crusted, or scabby for a week or two.
diagnosis: Clinical. Can biopsy if uncertain to confirm dx.
management: Given self-limited nature, treatment may be unnecessary. However, can treat based on cosmetic reasons / presence of dermatitis / immunosuppression / lesions near perineal or genital area.+- topical cantharidin (a vesicant)+- cryotherapy+- curettage+- topical retinoids+- Aldara® (imiquimod)++Keep lesions covered if possible and avoid touching/picking to prevent transmission to other body parts or to others.
epid: This highly contagious viral infection most commonly affects children two to 11 years of age. It also occurs in sexually active adolescents. Giant molluscum and severe cases can be seen in the setting of HIV. Atopic dermatitis is a risk factor due to frequent breaks in the skin.
patho: Caused by DNA Pox virus (Molluscum contagiosum virus). Virus is spread via direct contact, auto-inoculation, sexual contact. Virus is self-limited and can take months to 1-2 yr to resolve spontaneously.
summary: Common and benign superficial skin disease caused by a poxvirus. Characterized by small pearly papules with a central depression. Diagnosed clinically. A self-limited infection.

Name: Psoriasis
tags: red, erythema, plaque, scale, itchy, tender, nail, silver, joint pain+pediatric, adult, family history, diabetes, smoking+non-emergent+chronic inflammatory
defin: A chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by defined, red and scaly plaques. Has subtypes.
symptoms: Dry or red areas of skin, covered by silvery-white scales and sometimes with raised edges. Can occur anywhere, but most commonly at elbows, knees, scalp, chest, and lower back. If in skin folds, plaques often appear shiny with a moist peeling surface.++Itching and skin pain, sometimes severe - may be itch cycle with lichenification. May have joint pain, swelling or stiffness, nail abnormalities. When psoriatic plaques clear up, they may leave brown or pale marks that can be expected to fade over several months. Psoriasis may be permanent or episodic & plaques are usually very persistent without treatment.
pe: Subtypes include plaque, guttate, pustular, inverse and erthyrodermic. Some of these types may evolve from plaque psoriasis.
diagnosis: Diagnosis of psoriasis involves taking a careful history and conducting a physical examination. Biopsy is rarely needed.
ddx: AD, mycosis fungoides (cutaneous T-cell lymphoma), seborrheic dermatitis, tinea, nummular dermatitis, lichen planus
management: Depends on severity of disease (ie by BSA affected). General lifestyle measures are smoking cessation, avoiding alcohol, maintaining optimal weight, using emollients. They should also be investigated for comorbidities associated with psoriasis.+Mild (<3% BSA)+Topicals 1st line: include topical corticosteroids, vitamin D3 analogues, retinoids, calcineurin inhibitors, anthralin and coal tar (most commonly start with topical steroids and/or topical vitamin D3 analogues, best tolerated). If lesions are scattered or in difficult to treat sites (palms, soles, scalp, genitals) consider phototherapy or systemic treatment.+Moderate to severe+Referral should be considered. Goal is symptom control. Continue with topicals, add phototherapy if possible, and use systemic therapy (ie DMARDs / biologics) based on patient’s treatment history and comorbidities
epid: Peaks of onset: 20-30 yr old and 50-60 yr old. Most people who get psoriasis have it for life.  Psoriasis occurs equally among men and women. Polygenic inheritance. Risk factors: smoking, obesity, FHx, alcohol, drugs, infections, physical trauma (Koebner phenomenon)+Associated comorbidities: depression, anxiety and suicide. Arthritis, cardiac events, diabetes, cancer, liver disease.
patho: Psoriasis has a genetic basis and about one-third of people with psoriasis have at least one family member with the disease. While the exact cause of psoriasis has not yet been determined, researchers believe it involves a combination of genetic, environmental and immune factors.+Flare-up triggers: emotional stress, local injury to skin, systemic infections, and the use of certain medications (ie Li, beta blockers, oral steroids with overuse or abrupt stop), dry cold weather in winter
summary: Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory skin disease most commonly presenting with defined, red and scaly plaques. Diagnosis is mainly clinical, and focus of management is symptom control. First line treatments are topicals, but more severe cases will need systemic treatment (DMARDs/biologicals) and will likely need referral.

Name: Rosacea
tags: papule, pustule, red, erythema, flushing, telangiectasia, phyma, eye, ocular, face+adult, white, female+non-emergent+inflammatory
defin: Rosacea is a chronic facial skin condition characterized by marked involvement of the central face.
symptoms: Marked involvement of central face with transient or persistent erythema, inflammatory papules or pustules, telangiectasia, or hyperplasia of the connective tissue. Transient erythema/flushing, usually <5mins and may spread to the neck and chest. Characterized by remissions and exacerbations. Exacerbating factors: heat, cold, wind, sun, stress, drinking hot liquids, alcohol, spices
pe: Dome-shaped inflammatory papules ± pustules. May see flushing, non-transient erythema, and telangiectasia. Distribution: typically on central face including forehead, nose, cheeks, and chin -> rarely on scalp, neck, and upper body. In longstanding rosacea, signs of thickening, induration and lymphedema in the skin can develop:+- phyma: a distinct swelling caused by lymphedema and hypertrophy of subcutaneous tissue, particularly affecting the nose (rhinophyma)+- ocular manifestations: blepharoconjunctivitis, keratitis, iritis++4 subtypes: erythematotelangiectatic, papulopustular, phymatous, and ocular
diagnosis: Presence of one or more of the following primary features: Flushing (transient erythema), Nontransient erythema, Papules and pustules, Telangiectasia+May include one or more of the following secondary features: Burning or stinging, Dry appearance, Edema, Phymatous changes, Ocular manifestations, Peripheral location
ddx: Acne vulgaris, seborrheic dermatitis, perioral dermatitis, contact dermatitis. Rosacea can be differentiated from acne by the absence of comedones, a predilection for the central face and symptoms of flushing.
management: Treatment decisions can be quite nuanced and are based on severity -> please see linked articles below for more information.+General measures: Avoid triggers -> helpful to journal documenting exposures, diet, and activities that cause flare-ups. Avoid topical corticosteroids. Gentle skin care, regular moisturizer, lots of sunscreen / photoprotection+Pharm interventions+- topical or oral antibiotics or topical azelaic acid or ivermectin+- flushing or persistent erythema, consideration of topical brimonidine or oxymetazoline+- For recalcitrant cases, consideration of oral isotretinoin+- For rhinophyma, consideration of dermabrasion, laser ablation, and tissue excision+- For telangiectasia, consideration of laser or electrocautery treatment+
epid: Although found in all skin types, highest prevalence in fair-skinned people. 30-50 yr old. F>M. Associated with psychiatric comorbidity.
summary: Rosacea is a chronic inflammatory disorder characterized by facial flushing, telangiectasias, erythema, papules, pustules, and, in severe cases, rhinophyma. Diagnosis is based on the characteristic appearance and history. Treatment depends on severity and includes topical metronidazole, topical and oral antibiotics, topical ivermectin, rarely isotretinoin, and, for severe rhinophyma, surgery.

Name: Roseola
tags: maculopapular, fever, febrile, blanchable, red, erythema, trunk, not itchy, not painful+pediatric, common+non-emergent+viral, infectious
defin: Extremely common pediatric infection caused mostly by HHV-6B, characterized by fever and post-defervescence rash.
symptoms: Abrupt onset of high fever (ie >39°C) lasting a few days, with otherwise well looking child - no focal clinical signs except possible mild cough, rhinorrhea, or mild diarrhea. After/during resolution of fever, an erythematous macular to maculopapular rash typically appears, starting on the trunk and spreading peripherally
pe: Erythematous macular to maculopapular rash spreading from the trunk. Non-pruritic, not painful. Blanchable. Some spots may be surrounded by a lighter halo of pale skin. Similar spots may occur on soft palate and uvula (Nagayama spots). May fade within a few hours or persist for as long as two days
ddx: Can be confused with measles. However, measles rash begins on the face, and the child is usually ill-appearing
epid: Roseola is so common that most children have been infected with roseola by the time they enter kindergarten.
patho: Caused by human herpesvirus 6B (HHV-6B) or, less commonly, HHV-7
summary: Roseola infantum is an infection of infants or very young children caused by human herpesvirus 6B (HHV-6B) or, less commonly, HHV-7. The infection causes high fever and a rubelliform eruption that occurs during or after defervescence, but localizing symptoms or signs are absent. Diagnosis is clinical, and treatment is symptomatic

Name: Seborrheic dermatitis
tags: red, itchy, scaly, greasy, yellow, white, flakes, dandruff, oily+pediatric, adult, Parkinson, immunocomprimise+Non-emergent+inflammatory, fungal
defin: A common dermatitis mainly affecting areas with high density of sebaceous glands, such as the scalp. Greasy scaly flaking patches, erythema, and dandruff.
symptoms: Tends to develop gradually. Associated with itch (especially scalp/ear canal), may burn, often dandruff. Common sites include: scalp, eyebrows, eyelashes, beard, glabella, post-auricular, over sternum, trunk, body folds, genitalia
pe: Adults/Adolescents:+Greasy, erythematous base, yellow, scaling, minimally elevated papules and plaques in areas rich in sebaceous glands, can look moist and supercially eroded in flexural regions. Scales can flake and tend to be yellow/white+Newborn/Infants:+Thick, yellow, crusted scalp lesion (cradle cap). Fissuring and yellow scaling behind the ears, red facial papules, stubborn diaper rash
ddx: Atopic dermatitis of the scalp, Scalp psoriasis, Rosacea
management: Face:+ketoconazole (Nizoral®) cream daily or bid and/or mild steroid cream daily or bid+Scalp:+Salicylic acid in olive oil or Derma-Smoothe FS® lotion (mineral oil, fluocinolone acetonide 0.01%) to remove dense scales, 2% ketoconazole shampoo (Nizoral®), ciclopirox (Stieprox®) shampoo, selenium sulfide (e.g. Selsun®) or zinc pyrithione (e.g. Head and Shoulders®) shampoo, steroid lotion (e.g. betamethasone valerate 0.1% lotion bid)
epid: Most common in <3 months or 30-60 years of age. Increased incidence and severity in immunocompromised patients, neurological disease (ie Parkinson disease)
patho: Not well known, but possible etiologic association with Malassezia spp. (yeast). Seborrheic dermatitis does not cause hair loss
summary: Common dermatitis mainly affecting oily areas with greasy scaly patches. Diagnosed clinically and managed with topicals steroids/antifungals, shampoos

Name: Seborrheic keratosis
tags: papule, plaque, tan, brown, black, scale, crust, warty, greasy, waxy+adult, family history+Non-emergent+Benign growth
defin: Very common benign epithelial tumour of keratinocytes and melanocytes. ‘Wisdom spots,’ ‘age spots,’ or ‘barnacles of life’.
symptoms: Grows slowly. Rarely pruritic. Non-tender. Sites: face, trunk, upper extremities (may occur at any site except palms or soles). Note: Leser-Trelat sign → sudden appearance of SK associated with malignancy, commonly gastric adenocarcinomas
pe: Well-demarcated waxy papule/plaque with classic “stuck on” appearance, ranging in colour from light tan to brown or black. The classic textbook appearance is a scaling or crusted surface. Over time lesions appear more warty, greasy and pigmented. Size can vary from small to >2.5cm. May appear in clusters.
diagnosis: Clinical. Biopsy only if diagnosis uncertain
ddx: malignant melanoma, melanocytic nevi, pigmented BCC, solar lentigo, spreading pigmented AK
management: None required, for cosmetic purposes only. Cryotherapy, electrodessication, excision. Of note, creams, ointments, or other medication can neither cure nor prevent seborrheic keratoses.
epid: Unusual <30 years old. M>F. Autosomal dominant inheritance. Very common lesion in older populations
patho: Benign epithelial tumour due to proliferation of keratinocytes and melanocytes. Transformation is not an issue.
summary: Common benign epithelial tumour in older populations that is diagnosed clinically. Treatment is cosmetic.

Name: Squamous cell carcinoma
tags: indurated, tender, ulcer, papule, plaque, nodule, scale, crust, irregular+sun exposed, adult, immunosuppresion+emergent+malignancy, cancer
defin: Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a common type of keratinocyte cancer.
symptoms: Patients may describe a nonhealing lesion that bleeds with minimal trauma. Lesion may be itchy, tender, ulcerated, and located on sun-exposed areas. Grows over weeks to months. Ask for constitutional symptoms.
pe: Hyperkeratotic indurated, pink/red/skin-coloured papule/plaque/nodule with surface scale/crust ±central ulceration/atrophy/erosion. Lesions often appear dry and can bleed with abrasion, may look irregular and ‘heaped up’. Several phenotypes (ie exophytic cutaneous horn). Most common sites: face, ears, scalp, forearms, dorsum of hands
diagnosis: Biospy. Initial tissue sampling can be shave if raised lesion, punch of most abnormal area, or complete excision if lesion is small enough. If there is ANY concern for melanoma, need full-thickness sample.
ddx: benign: nummular eczema, psoriasis, irritated seborrheic keratosis+pre-malignant: Actinic Keratosis, Bowenoid papulosis+malignant: keratoacanthoma, Bowen’s disease, BCC, amelanotic melanoma
management: Consider referral to plastics / derm / ENT for surgical excision, the main treatment for SCC in situ. Mohs surgery. Lifelong follow-up (more aggressive treatment than BCC). Prevention: very careful sun protection
epid: Second most common type of cutaneous neoplasm. Primarily on sun-exposed skin in the elderly, M>F. Most common cutaneous cancer in organ transplant recipients.+good prognostic factors: early treatment, negative margins, and small size of lesion+- SCCs from AK metastasize less frequently (~1%) than other SCCs arising de novo+- overall control is 75% over 5 yr, rate of metastasis from primary SCC is 2-5%+- metastasis rates are higher if diameter >2 cm, depth >4 mm, recurrent, involvement of bone/muscle/nerve, location on scalp/ears/nose/lips, immunosuppressed, caused by arsenic ingestion, or tumour arose from scar/chronic ulcer/burn/genital tract/sinus tract
patho: Malignant neoplasm of keratinocytes (primarily vertical growth). Predisposing factors include: cumulative UV radiation, AK, PUVA, ionizing radiation therapy/exposure, chemical carcinogens (such as arsenic, tar, and nitrogen mustards), HPV 16, 18, immunosuppression. May occur in previous scar (SCC more commonly than BCC).
summary: Cutaneous SCC is a common keratinocyte cancer most common in areas of sun exposure, often presenting with a hyperkeratotic indurated, pink/red/skin-coloured papule/plaque/nodule. Diagnosis is by biopsy, and treatment is largely excisional with lifelong follow-up.
